title: A Mixtape For Walking Around The City
content: I had a lot more time to listen to music this week. The result is quite satisfying, I have about 25 new songs from just the last 6 days.I also took some time to remove duplicate songs and songs I wasn‚Äôt too sure about from my main playlist on Spotify.Here goes this week‚Äôs playlist. Perfect for walking around the city while forgetting about everything else.2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 3Reptilia by The StrokesCatavento by Dave GrusinSONGS ABOUT YOU by CHIKAStay Alive by MustafaThis one is so mellow and sweet. It never fails to put a smile on my face. üòäMy Song by Labi SiffreAgua de Beber by Ant√¥nio Carlos Jobim, Astrud Gilberto and Marty PaichDean Town by VulfpeckMascaram Sebata by Mulatu Astatke and Black Jesus ExperienceHere‚Äôs the full playlist.

title: A New Start
content: There had to be a first post on here, so here goes nothing.What better way to start off the new year (2021) than with some fresh (and some not so fresh) finds.2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 0Better by Cody Fry, Cory Wong, DynamoSomeone Like You by AdeleHome by Cory WongCall Your Name by ToraLOVE AGAIN by Daniel CaesarThe obligatory Daniel Caesar song, of course.Concorde by Gregory PorterPhoenix by Gregory PorterThis one had me scratch my head as to where I had heard it before.I still haven‚Äôt figured it out. Maybe it‚Äôs just one of those songs that feels ‚Äúright‚Äù from the get-go.Midnight by Lianne La Havas - Live At The RoundhouseThis one‚Äôs kind of a hint at what‚Äôs coming next week. I‚Äôve got a lot more of her songs I‚Äôd like to discover.I‚Äôll try to keep this post short nevertheless.Here‚Äôs the full playlist for anyone interested.

title: Example content
content: Howdy! This is an example blog post that shows several types of HTML content supported in this theme.Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Sed posuere consectetur est at lobortis. Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum.  Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur.Inline HTML elementsHTML defines a long list of available inline tags, a complete list of which can be found on the Mozilla Developer Network.  To bold text, use <strong>.  To italicize text, use <em>.  To highlight, use <mark>.  Abbreviations, like HTML should use <abbr>, with an optional title attribute for the full phrase.  Citations, like ‚Äî Mark Otto, should use <cite>.  Deleted text should use <del> and inserted text should use <ins>.  Superscript text uses <sup> and subscript text uses <sub>.Most of these elements are styled by browsers with few modifications on our part.FootnotesFootnotes are supported as part of the Markdown syntax. Here‚Äôs one in action. Clicking this number1 will lead you to a footnote. The syntax looks like:Clicking this number[^fn-sample_footnote]Each footnote needs the ^fn- prefix and a unique ID to be referenced for the footnoted content. The syntax for that list looks something like this:[^fn-sample_footnote]: Handy! Now click the return link to go back.You can place the footnoted content wherever you like. Markdown parsers should properly place it at the bottom of the post.HeadingVivamus sagittis lacus vel augue rutrum faucibus dolor auctor. Duis mollis, est non commodo luctus, nisi erat porttitor ligula, eget lacinia odio sem nec elit. Morbi leo risus, porta ac consectetur ac, vestibulum at eros.CodeInline code is available with the <code> element. Snippets of multiple lines of code are supported through Rouge. Longer lines will automatically scroll horizontally when needed. You may also use code fencing (triple backticks) for rendering code.// Example can be run directly in your JavaScript console// Create a function that takes two arguments and returns the sum of those argumentsvar adder = new Function("a", "b", "return a + b");// Call the functionadder(2, 6);// > 8You may also optionally show code snippets with line numbers. Add linenos to the Rouge tags.12345678// Example can be run directly in your JavaScript console// Create a function that takes two arguments and returns the sum of those argumentsvar adder = new Function("a", "b", "return a + b");// Call the functionadder(2, 6);// > 8Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur. Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Fusce dapibus, tellus ac cursus commodo, tortor mauris condimentum nibh, ut fermentum massa.Gists via GitHub PagesVestibulum id ligula porta felis euismod semper. Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Donec sed odio dui.Using HTML:Using jekyll-gist:Aenean eu leo quam. Pellentesque ornare sem lacinia quam venenatis vestibulum. Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Donec sed odio dui. title: Music To Help Soothe Lonely Hearts
content: Another week of 2020 has gone by and things have been, well, strange. I haven‚Äôt been able to tell whether we‚Äôre headed somewhere much worse or much better.As a new semester begins, I might not have as much time to listen to music as I did these past weeks. As such, this may be my most prolific week of the next two to three months (with regards to how much music I listen to at least).2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 1This is probably the song that moved me the most this week.anything by Adrianne LenkerThe sensitivity in Adrianne Lenker‚Äôs voice is unsettling. The lyrics also contribute to the beauty of the song:  And I don‚Äôt wanna talk about anythingI don‚Äôt wanna talk about anythingI wanna kiss, kiss your eyes againWanna witness your ey–µs lookingI don‚Äôt wanna talk about anyoneI don‚Äôt wanna talk about anyoneI wanna sleep in your car while you‚Äôr–µ drivingLay in your lap when I‚Äôm cryingLover, You Should‚Äôve Come Over by Jeff BuckleyWe change repertoire with a group that was completely new to me: ‚ÄúTank and The Bangas‚Äù.Ants by Tank and The BangasNovember Has Come by GorillazThis song had always been one of my favorite off Gorillaz‚Äôs Demon Days, but I never realized it was DOOM rapping these verses. In homage to the illest villain.Vaudeville Villain by Viktor VaughnAnother DOOM song I rediscovered recently.Bittersweet - Full Length by Lianne La HavasA little bit more of Lianne La Havas from last week.Need You Tonight by INXSNo matter how many times I‚Äôve listened to this one, it still sends chills down my spine.The Sun Is In Your Eyes - Voice Memo by Jacob CollierHere‚Äôs the full playlist.

title: New Songs To Drown Out The Noise
content: I was really tired this week. I‚Äôm not sure if I got sick.2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 4Too Good by Arlo ParksCranes in the Sky by SolangeA N√≠vel De‚Ä¶ by Jo√£o BoscoWhat Kinda Music by Tom Misch, Yussef DayesDon‚Äôt Leave Me This Way by Harold Melvin, The Blue Notes, Teddy PendergrassLove and Happiness by Al GreenRhymes Like Dimes by MF DOOM, DJ Cucumber SliceGrace And Mercy by Immanuel WilkinsJust some really good jazz.Here‚Äôs the full playlist.

title: Space Songs
content: This week, I rediscovered Cowboy Bebop‚Äôs incredible soundtrack that‚Äôs now1 available in its entirety on Spotify! ü•≥Of course, there were many other discoveries, but it‚Äôs probably what I listened to the most this week.2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 2Cosmos by SEATBELTSSpokey Dokey by SEATBELTSRoad Of The Lonely Ones by MadlibOnce A Day by Mac MillerI also revisited the two Mac Miller albums Swimming and Circles. Both are mellow masterpieces.Walkin‚Äô Back to Georgia by Jim CrocePut Your Records On by Corinne Bailey RaeRehab by Amy WinehousePick Up The Pieces - Live at Montreux 1977 by Average White BandAs always, here‚Äôs the full playlist.            Actually it‚Äôs been available there since 24-07-2020 but I only learned about it recently.¬†↩

title: The End Of Yet Another Semester
content: I can finally post a new playlist!2021 Weekly Playlist - Week 17Honky Cat by Elton JohnDon‚Äôt Think Twice, It‚Äôs All Right by Bob DylanI‚Äôll Be Lucky Someday by Glenn CampbellCalifornia Girls by The Beach BoysSad Lisa by Yusuf / Cat StevensDon‚Äôt Stop by Fleetwood MacNight Fever by Bee GeesLove Of My Life by QueenDiamonds On The Soles Of Her Shoes by Paul SimonThe full playlist is here.

title: Windows 10 Tweaks To Make It Bearable
content: Step 1: Remove All Bundled Apps (except the Store)In an admin powershell enter:Get-AppxPackage -AllUsers | where-object {$_.name ‚Äìnotlike "*store*"} | Remove-AppxPackageStep 2: Disable TelemetryMethod #1 - regeditCreate a new DWORD (32 bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\DataCollection named AllowTelemetry with a value of 0.Method #2 - services.mscSet Connected User Experiences and Telemetry‚Äôs startup type to Disabled.Step 3: If I Have Access To The Group Policy EditorCortana and Windows SearchIn (Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Search):  Disable ‚ÄúAllow Cortana‚Äù.  Disable ‚ÄúPrevent automatically adding shared folders to the Windows Search index‚Äù.  Enable ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt search the web or display web results in search‚Äù.Data Collection and Preview BuildsIn (Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Data Collection and Preview Builds):  Enable ‚ÄúAllow Telemetry‚Äù and set it to ‚Äú0 - Off [Enterprise Only]‚Äù.  Enable ‚ÄúDo not show feedback notifications‚Äù.WiFi SenseIn (Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Network\WLAN Service\WLAN Settings\):  Disable ‚ÄúAllow Windows to automatically connect to suggested open hotspots, to networks shared by contacts, and to hotspots offering paid services‚Äù.Microsoft Data CollectionIn (Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Windows Components\Application Compatibility):  Enable ‚ÄúTurn off Application Telemetry‚Äù.  Enable ‚ÄúTurn off Inventory Collector‚Äù.Microsoft Customer Experience  Enable ‚ÄúTurn off Microsoft consumer experiences‚Äù.Step 4: Registry Hacks  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\Current\Version\Explorer\Advanced named LastActiveClick with a value of 1.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Personalization named NoLockScreen with a value of 1.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\TimeZoneInformation named RealTimeIsUniversal with a value of 1.          This makes Windows use UTC which is useful when dual-booting MacOS or Linux.        Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\System named DisableLogonBackgroundImage with a value of 1.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\Windows Error Reporting named Disabled with a value of 1.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Advanced named LaunchTo with a value of 1.          Opens File Explorer on This PC by default.        Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\Desktop named JPEGImportQuality with a value of 100.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Windows Search] named AllowCortana with a value of 0.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Windows Search] named DisableWebSearch with a value of 1.  Create a new DWORD (32-bit) in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Explorer named DisableSearchBoxSuggestions with a value of 1.Wrapping upYou can check this and that out as well.

title: About
content:
About Me

I‚Äôm a McGill software engineering student who‚Äôs curious about most things that surround him. I‚Äôm currently learning the following: machine learning, HDLs, x86 assembly, how to write compilers, Coq, and Mandarin Chinese.

I‚Äôm interested in artificial intelligence, programming languages (type systems, memory management, etc.), algorithms, game theory and mathematics in general, philosophy, physics, chess and poker.

I also like to spend time listening to music, reading novels and Hacker News, running, swimming, or climbing.

If you like music too, you can find my main playlist here.

I mostly listen to it in reverse order of date added since this is what reflects my current tastes in music the most.

Happy listening!

You can find me on GitHub, on Twitter or you can email me at lacroixgabriel@gmail.com.

title: Home
content:
Welcome visitor!

Here‚Äôs a rhodonea curve for the pleasure of your eyes. It can be expressed in polar coordinates as: \(r(\theta) = \cos(\frac{3}{7} \theta)\).



See recent changes.

title: Meta
content:
This website is a blog, a digital playground and a wiki.

It uses Jekyll and GitHub Pages to generate a static site and publish it each time I push to this repository.

Most of the content is therefore in markdown and is added to a default HTML layout automatically.

License

The following directories of the repository and their contents are Copyright Gabriel Lacroix. You may not reuse anything therein without my permission:


  _pages
  _notes
  assets/images


All other directories and files use the GNU General Public License v3.0.
